G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: (Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment — G.L. c. 186, §14)

Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186,.proposition: Defendant’s failure constitutes a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her dwelling, in violation of Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186, §14, and related case law.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord is prohibited from directly or indirectly interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of her dwelling by action or omission.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a719 and \u00a721.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, §19 and §21, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant’s continued failure to provide adequate hot water constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, which requires that landlords provide and maintain operable facilities for safe hot water.

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: The deprivation of hot water for an extended period constitutes a condition which “seriously interferes with the health or safety” of the occupants as defined by 105 C.M.R. 410.750 and constitutes interference within the meaning of M.G.L. c. 186, §14.

M.G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the notion that malicious or specific intent to deprive the tenant is required for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It explains that a breach exists where substantial interference with use and enjoyment (including failure to supply essential services like heat and light) is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions, regardless of intent. The court cites Charles E. Burt (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services) as an example of such a breach without focusing on malice, thereby supporting the proposition as to heat and hot water.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover interference with quiet enjoyment without requiring malicious or specific intent, holding that at least reckless conduct suffices. However, the opinion does not specifically involve interference with heat or hot water, and it leaves intact the statutory requirement that failure to provide essential services (like heat or hot water) must be “willful or intentional.” Thus, it does not support the broader proposition that interference with essential services constitutes a breach even absent malicious intent across the board.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct — failure to provide services and interference with quiet enjoyment — were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’… The requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause; landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment… we… conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss interference with essential services such as heat or hot water at all. Instead, it clarifies that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) requires at least negligent conduct and that strict liability (here under the lead paint statute) is insufficient. While the case removes any requirement of malicious intent, it does not involve or specifically address essential services, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. … Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14.”

Winthrop v. O\u2019Brien, 25 Mass. App..raw_text: Winthrop v. O’Brien, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 514 (1988)
Winthrop v. O\u2019Brien, 25 Mass. App..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Winthrop v. O\u2019Brien, 25 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about wanton injury to personal property under G.L. c. 266, § 127, arising from damage to a police officer’s car. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or interference with essential services like heat or hot water. Because the case neither discusses nor decides any issue related to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it cannot be authority for the stated Massachusetts landlord‑tenant proposition.
Winthrop v. O\u2019Brien, 25 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “On May 1, 1985, there was an anti-apartheid student demonstration at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. While participating in the demonstration, the defendant damaged a 1984 Plymouth Turismo automobile which belonged to an officer in the university police department… [T]he defendant was found not guilty on that charge but guilty of the lesser offense of wanton injury to the car… Applying these principles to the Commonwealth’s proof, we think the evidence sufficient to warrant a finding that the defendant’s act was wanton or reckless.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does involve breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it concerns a landlord’s failure to address criminal drug activity in common areas, not interference with essential services like heat or hot water. The opinion reiterates that breach turns on whether serious interference is the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of what the landlord did or failed to do, not on malicious intent, but it does not address utility shutoffs or essential services. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about heat or hot water, though it supports a broader no-malice-required standard for quiet enjoyment breaches.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

Doe v. Springfield Hous. Auth., 428 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. Springfield Hous. Auth., 428 Mass. 906 (1999)
Doe v. Springfield Hous. Auth., 428 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.

Cox v. Ruef, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985).raw_text: Cox v. Ruef, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985)
Cox v. Ruef, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Cox v. Ruef, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985).support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a criminal speedy-trial / Rule 36 decision and does not involve landlord-tenant law, essential services, quiet enjoyment, or interference with heat or hot water. Nothing in the court’s reasoning or holding addresses covenants of quiet enjoyment or the effect of service interruptions, with or without malicious intent. Accordingly, this case cannot be authority for the stated Massachusetts landlord-tenant proposition.
Cox v. Ruef, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1985).relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt. The opinion deals exclusively with speedy-trial calculations under Mass. R. Crim. P. 36 in a criminal prosecution, not with quiet enjoyment or essential services. ]

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s statutory obligation under the State Sanitary Code to provide heat and hot water and holds that an oral agreement shifting that duty to the tenant is ineffective because the Code requires a written agreement. However, the case does not analyze or decide any claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address whether interference with essential services constitutes such a breach or whether malicious intent is required. It is therefore not authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, interference with essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent malicious intent.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that loss of heat and hot water is a material breach of the warranty of habitability and grounds for rent abatement without regard to the landlord’s fault. However, the case is framed and decided purely in terms of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not the statutory or common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment. It therefore supports strict liability for interference with essential services under the warranty of habitability, but does not itself establish that such interference constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment absent malicious intent.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability…. We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.”
